newsitem.title: GERMANY: German SPD's Schroeder counsels EMU delay.
newsitem.headline: German SPD's Schroeder counsels EMU delay.

text.p: Gerhard Schroeder, a leading Social Democrat potential candidate for chancellor, said it would be better to delay the launch of Europe's planned single currency than to soften the criteria, Die Zeit newspaper reported on Wednesday.

"One must maintain the stability criteria and advise a controlled delay," he said in an interview with the German weekly released ahead of publication on Thursday. "I would see that as less bad than to ignore the criteria and give up the stability orientation."
Schroeder said the French Socialist victory in Sunday's elections should not be seen by the German SPD as a signal to push for a loosening of the EMU criteria.
"I believe we would be making a gigantic mistake if we were to distance ourselves too far from stability policy," he said.
"Now to say, 'Thank God, we have the support of France, let's soften the criteria,' would be to misunderstand our specific German situation."
Schroeder said the Socialist victory in France would slow the political process in Europe, and hinder "the realisation of the ambitious, partly egotistical, goals of (Chancellor Helmut) Kohl."

Schroeder said that by "controlled delay," he meant a narrowing of the bands in the European rate mechanism, and an implementation of the stability pact before the start of EMU, to see whether it functions.
"If one were now to try to start currency union no matter what the cost, the damage would exceed the benefit," he said.
